creator.name: Koning / Staatssecretarie / Kabinet des Konings
creator.his_func:
According to the constitution of 1815 the king was given direct supervision and control over all Dutch colonies in east and west. The colonial administrations had to account for their actions to the Ministry of the Colonies, but all decisions and regulations regarding the colonial government were issued by royal decree. Only in 1848 did the Dutch parliament become involved in the colonial administration.

Under the reign of King Willem I (1813/1815-1840), the State Secretariat (Staatssecretarie) was the main coordinating instrument for the government. It was responsible for the issuing the King's Decrees (Besluiten) and laws. The King's Secretariat (Kabinet des Konings) was a sort of private secretariat and also a part of the State Secretariat. King Willem II established a new Secretariat of the King on the first of January 1841. It consisted of the former King's Secretariat and the State Secretariat.

After the Constitution of 1848, the focus of policy-making shifted gradually to the ministries, reducing the informative value of the archive of the King’s Secretariat.
